unnormalised: I remember when online learning was just starting out. Back then, around 2015 or so, my younger brother, Rohan, was prepping for his JEE exams. Coaching centres were charging a bomb, like Rs. 50,000 for a few months! My dad, being a government employee, couldn’t really afford it. That’s when we stumbled upon this EdTech platform, something called "LearnSmart," offering courses for just Rs. 5000. We were sceptical, but Rohan needed the help.
normalised: I remember when online learning was just starting out. Back then, around two thousand and fifteen or so, my younger brother, Rohan, was prepping for his J-E-E exams. Coaching centres were charging a bomb, like rupee fifty thousand for a few months! My dad, being a government employee, couldn’t really afford it. That’s when we stumbled upon this E-d-T-e-c-h platform, something called "LearnSmart," offering courses for just rupee five thousand. We were sceptical, but Rohan needed the help.

unnormalised: Turns out, it was a game-changer! He could watch lectures at his own pace, take practice tests anytime, even at 2 AM if he wanted. The instructors were from IIT, which was a big deal. He still remembers Mr. Sharma from the platform, who taught Physics so well. He ended up scoring 92%ile, which was enough to get him into a decent engineering college. Now, even my uncle in Kerala is telling everyone about Byju's, saying it's the best thing since sliced bread.

unnormalised: It's amazing how much EdTech has grown since then. There are so many options now, from coding classes for kids (WhiteHat Jr., I think?) to online MBA programs costing upwards of Rs. 2 lakh. It’s definitely made education more accessible, especially for students in smaller towns who don't have access to the best teachers. Plus, you don't have to deal with the Delhi traffic!
